sites.name: Pyramids of Giza
sites.shortDescription: The last surviving wonder of the ancient world.

subLocations.name: Great Pyramid of Khufu
subLocations.shortDescription: The largest and oldest of the three pyramids

storyCards.content: Standing 481 feet tall, the Great Pyramid was the tallest structure on Earth for over 3,800 years.
Built around 2560 BCE for Pharaoh Khufu. It took roughly 20 years and 100,000 workers to complete.

storyCards.funFact: The pyramid contains about 2.3 million stone blocks, each weighing 2.5 tons on average!

quizQuestion.question: Who was the Great Pyramid built for?
quizQuestion.explanation: The Great Pyramid was built as a tomb for Pharaoh Khufu (also known as Cheops) of the Fourth Dynasty.

storyCards.content: Inside are three chambers: the King's Chamber with a granite sarcophagus, the Queen's Chamber, and an unfinished underground chamber.

storyCards.funFact: The four sides of the pyramid are aligned almost perfectly with the four cardinal directions!

subLocations.name: The Great Sphinx
subLocations.shortDescription: The mysterious guardian with a lion's body and human head

storyCards.content: The Great Sphinx is the oldest and largest monolith statue in the world, carved from a single limestone bedrock.
Standing 66 feet high and 240 feet long, the Sphinx has the body of a lion and the face believed to be of Pharaoh Khafre.

storyCards.funFact: The Sphinx's nose is missing! Contrary to legend, it wasn't shot off by Napoleon's soldiers.

quizQuestion.question: What does 'Abu al-Hol' (Arabic name) mean?
quizQuestion.explanation: The Arabic name 'Abu al-Hol' translates to 'Father of Terror' or 'Father of Dread'.

subLocations.name: Pyramid of Khafre
subLocations.shortDescription: The second-largest pyramid built for Khufu's son

storyCards.content: Though slightly smaller than the Great Pyramid, Khafre's pyramid appears taller because it's built on higher ground.
It's the only pyramid that still has some of its original white limestone casing at the top, giving us a glimpse of how all pyramids once gleamed.

storyCards.funFact: The pyramids were originally covered in polished white limestone that would have shone brilliantly in the sun!

subLocations.name: Solar Boat Museum
subLocations.shortDescription: Houses a reconstructed ancient boat buried near the Great Pyramid

storyCards.content: In 1954, archaeologists discovered a 4,600-year-old boat buried in a pit beside the Great Pyramid.
The boat was found in 1,224 pieces. It took 14 years to carefully reassemble this ancient vessel.

storyCards.funFact: At 143 feet long, it's one of the oldest and largest ancient vessels ever found!

quizQuestion.question: What was the solar boat's purpose?
options: Carry the pharaoh's soul to the afterlife
quizQuestion.explanation: The solar boat was meant to carry the pharaoh's soul across the heavens with the sun god Ra.

visitInfo.bestTimeToVisit: Early morning (8-10 AM) or late afternoon
tips: Bring plenty of water and sun protection
Hire an official guide at the entrance
The interior of the Great Pyramid is hot and cramped

sites.name: Luxor Temple
sites.shortDescription: A stunning temple in the heart of modern Luxor beautiful at night.

subLocations.name: The Grand Entrance
subLocations.shortDescription: Massive pylons and the remaining obelisk

storyCards.content: Two massive seated statues of Ramesses II guard the entrance, each standing 50 feet tall.
Originally, two obelisks stood here. One remains in Luxor; the other has been in Paris since 1836.

storyCards.funFact: The missing obelisk now stands in Place de la Concorde in Paris - a gift from Egypt to France!

visitInfo.bestTimeToVisit: Evening visit recommended - beautifully lit at night
tips: Visit at sunset to see the temple transform
The temple is in central Luxor - easy walk from hotels
Look for the Abu Haggag Mosque built on top

sites.name: Valley of the Kings
sites.shortDescription: The hidden burial ground of Egypt's greatest pharaohs.

subLocations.name: Tomb of Tutankhamun
subLocations.shortDescription: The famous tomb of the boy king

storyCards.content: In 1922, Howard Carter made the discovery of a lifetime - the nearly intact tomb of a young pharaoh.
"Can you see anything?" Lord Carnarvon asked. "Yes, wonderful things," Carter whispered, peering through a small hole.

storyCards.funFact: It took Carter 10 years to catalog all 5,398 objects found in the tomb!

quizQuestion.question: Why was Tutankhamun's tomb so significant?
quizQuestion.explanation: Unlike most royal tombs which were robbed in antiquity, Tut's tomb was found nearly intact with all its treasures.

visitInfo.bestTimeToVisit: Early morning (6-8 AM) before the heat
tips: Your ticket includes 3 tombs - choose wisely
Tutankhamun's tomb requires a separate ticket

sites.name: Karnak Temple Complex
sites.shortDescription: The largest ancient religious complex ever built.

subLocations.name: Great Hypostyle Hall
subLocations.shortDescription: 134 massive columns in a forest of stone

storyCards.content: You stand among giants. 134 massive columns surround you, the largest standing 69 feet tall.
Imagine this space 3,000 years ago: columns painted in brilliant colors, incense smoke drifting through light.

storyCards.funFact: The entire Notre-Dame cathedral could fit inside the Hypostyle Hall!

visitInfo.bestTimeToVisit: Early morning or evening Sound & Light show
tips: The complex is vast - wear comfortable shoes
The Hypostyle Hall is best in morning light

sites.name: Abu Simbel
sites.shortDescription: Ramesses II's monumental temple famously relocated.

subLocations.name: Great Temple of Ramesses II
subLocations.shortDescription: Four colossal statues guard the entrance

storyCards.content: Four massive statues of Ramesses II gaze eternally across the Nubian desert, each 65 feet tall.
Twice a year, on Feb 22 and Oct 22, the rising sun penetrates 185 feet into the mountain to illuminate the inner statues.

storyCards.funFact: The entire temple was moved in the 1960s to save it from flooding! Cut into blocks and reassembled on higher ground.

quizQuestion.question: Why was Abu Simbel moved?
options: To save it from Lake Nasser flooding
quizQuestion.explanation: The Aswan High Dam would have submerged the temple. UNESCO led an international effort to relocate it.

visitInfo.bestTimeToVisit: Feb 22 or Oct 22 for the sun festival
